subtitle: Ask yourself some questions
title: Think you are ready for sex?
content:
As your body develops during puberty, you’ll start to think more about sex. When you have sexual feelings for someone, thinking about them or being around them will make you feel sexually excited. 

These feelings are all part of growing up but it’s how you deal with them that is important! 

**You want to have sex, but are you old enough?** 
If you’re under 16 it’s illegal to have sex. This law is there to protect you. You might feel sexual about someone and your body will feel ready for sex, but your mind and emotions may not be ready. Sex comes with many grown-up responsibilities, like becoming a parent and dealing with possible sexually transmitted infections (STIs). 

**Is it really your choice right now?** 

 - What are your values? 
 - Is someone pressuring you, do you feel comfortable with this person? 
 - Do you feel like you can say no or change your mind at any time?  
 - Do you think it’s better to wait? 
 - Are you pressuring someone else?
 - Are you old enough? 
 - Do you know how to use contraception (condoms) to avoid pregnancy or disease? 

**Are you under pressure?**
Having sex with someone is not the only way to show that you love them. When you’re old enough to have sex, it is still your right to decide if you want to or not. There are many other steps to dating that should come before sex, like kissing and holding hands. 
You may also feel pressure from your friends who tell you that they’re having sex (even if they aren’t!).  It’s tough to stand your ground, but it’s important to care for yourself first.

**Know your body rights: you choose when to have sex. Delay your first sexual encounter until you are sure you feel ready. Then, talk to a doctor, nurse or counsellor about using contraception to protect yourself against pregnancy, HIV and sexually transmitted infections. If you want to finish school or go to college one day, safe sex is important.**
